title-group.article-title: Enlarging the evanescent field scope by nanoparticle scattering for nanoparticle sensing of optical fiber sensors

abstract.p: A novel method to improve the sensitivity of evanescent field optical fiber sensors is proposed and confirmed by the numerical simulation. The evanescent field scope can be enlarged by nanoparticle scattering, which is produced by the nanoparticles placed in the evanescent field of the sensing fiber. It is found that the extent of nanoparticle scattering is dominated by the dimensions of the particles. Increasing the radius can enhance the scope of the evanescent filed. As the radius increases, the scattering peak shifts red and the scattering effect becomes obvious. The scattering efficiency accounts for about 74% of the extinction efficiency when the radius is 50 nm with the incident wavelength 420 nm. Moreover, the scope of the evanescent field can be extended to approximately 3 µm by silver nanoparticle scattering, which enhances the evanescent field to a relatively far-field scope.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Evanescent field optical fiber sensors are promising alternatives to traditional sensors for detecting chemicals, bacilli, toxins, and environmental pollutants because of their high efficiency, accuracy, low cost, and convenience.1,2 Many efforts have been made to improve the sensitivities of these sensors. Some researchers have attempted to increase the sensors’ sensitivities by optimizing the structures of the sensing fibers, for example, U-shaped, S-shaped, and tapered sensing fiber sensors are widely proposed and applied.3–5 Others improve the sensitivities of the sensors by modifying the refractive index of the analyte to satisfy the weakly guiding condition, which excites more evanescent field energy.6 Also, optical fiber evanescent field sensors of high sensitivity are obtained by decorating the surface of the sensing fibers with biochemical reagents or binding fluorescent dyes on the detecting molecules.7 Moreover, photonic crystal fibers can be used to improve the sensitivities of traditional absorption and fluorescence-based evanescent field optical fiber sensors dramatically owing to their ability to control their optical characteristics precisely. In photonic crystal fibers the energy interacting with the environment that is to be sensed is much higher than traditional sensing fibers. It is reported that the portion of the evanescent field energy interacting with the analytes is 6.5% for a multi-core photonic crystal fiber,8 40% for a nanowire,9 and 97% or higher for an air-core photonic bandgap fiber.10 However, these sensors require that the analytes to be measured are located within the holes of the photonic crystal fiber, and generally require filling of the fiber with liquids or gases, which make the sensors costly, sophisticated, and difficult to handle.

Here we propose a novel method to improve the sensitivity of the sensor through extending the evanescent field scope by using nanoparticles. When the scope is enlarged, more energy will interact with the analytes and the sensitivity of the sensor will be improved greatly. The scattering efficiency of silver nanoparticles illuminated by the evanescent field is theoretically studied. The relationship between the scattering efficiency and the sizes of the nanoparticles is discussed and analyzed thoroughly.

The penetration depth is a very important parameter in the study of evanescent field. Actually, the area of the evanescent field is mainly confined to within several hundred nanometers of the core–cladding interface around the sensing fiber, which is a typical near-field scope. Unfortunately, the penetration depth is far too small to be sensed. Therefore, enlarging the scope of the evanescent field will definitely improve the sensitivity.

sec.title: Mie theory and discrete dipole approximation (DDA)
sec.p: Mie theory presents a solution to Maxwell equations that describes the extinction spectra (extinction = scattering + absorption) of spherical particles of arbitrary size. Mie’s solution remains of great interest today, and it is the only simple, exact solution to Maxwell equations that is relevant to particles.11
DDA is a principle developed in recent years, which can be used to describe the optical properties of particles of any size and shape, such as absorption, scattering, and extinction.

In DDA, the particles are viewed as an aggregation comprising many cubic units, with each cubic unit considered a dipole. However, it is not confined in which cubic unit will be polarized, so the DDA method can be used to express nanoparticles of arbitrary shape and materials of multiple compositions. sec.title: Model description
sec.p: As a uniform evanescent wave exists on the sensing fiber surface, such an evanescent wave cannot be detected in the far-ﬁeld. Here, a new method to increase the sensitivity is proposed. When a nanoparticle is close to the surface of the sensing fiber, the scope of the evanescent field can be enlarged, and the energy of the evanescent field can be enhanced. The scope of the evanescent field can be extended to the far-field area by the nanoparticle scattering.

Figure 1 illustrates the sensing fiber used in the modeling, with part of its cladding removed. The sensing fiber is immersed into the testing media. The information of the analyte such as its reflective index, nmedia, and concentration can be obtained by measuring the output power of the sensing fiber. In the model, a silver nanoparticle which is placed in the vicinity of the sensing fiber interacts with the evanescent field above the core–cladding interface. Besides, because of the special property of the nanoparticle, the extinction process occurs, which includes both scattering and absorption. Here, we mainly consider the possibility of extending the reaction area of the evanescent field using nanoparticle scattering, which can improve the efficiency of the reaction between the evanescent field and the analyte.

sec.title: Simulation results
sec.p: The dependence of scattering efficiency on different sizes of silver nanoparticles has been numerically studied. Figure 2(a) indicates that the scattering effect is faint enough to be neglected for a spherical silver nanoparticle with a very small radius, such as 10 nm. To study further the working characteristics of the nanoparticle scattering effect, the extinction of nanoparticles with larger sizes has also been calculated. When the radius increases to 30 nm, the scattering efficiency improves obviously, and the scattering efficiency accounts for nearly 37.5% of the extinction efficiency, as is shown in Figure 2(b); and, when the size increases to 40 nm, the extinction efficiency is mainly determined by the scattering effect as depicted in Figure 2(c). As the radius of the nanosphere becomes large, the scattering effect becomes much more evident.

caption.p: Optical efficiency of silver nanospheres with different radii: (a) 10 nm; (b) 30 nm; (c) 40 nm; (d) 50 nm.

sec.p: The scattering efficiency curves of different sizes are illustrated in Figure 3(a). It can be concluded that the smaller the radius, the weaker is the scattering. As the radius increases, the scattering begins to play a major role in the extinction, which can improve the evanescent field distribution effectively. As shown in Figure 3(b), the ratio of the scattering efficiency to the extinction efficiency is 57% with a radius of 40 nm, and 74% with a radius of 50 nm. In addition, as the size increases, the scattering peak shifts red. The scattering peak wavelength shifts from 360 nm to 390 nm when the radius changes from 20 nm to 40 nm, and when the radius of the nanosphere is 50 nm the scattering peak wavelength moves to 410 nm, as depicted in Figure 3(c).

caption.p: (a) Scattering efficiency curves of nanospheres. (b) The ratio of the scattering efficiency to the extinction efficiency with different radii. (c) The scattering peak of different sizes.

sec.p: The extinction and scattering efficiency obtained in this part is under the condition that the nanoparticles are immersed in a free space. However, in the following simulation, the silver nanoparticles are placed in the vicinity of the sensing fiber; also the nanoparticles contribute to extending the reaction area of the evanescent field. The scope of the evanescent field can be spread further by the nanoparticle scattering effect.

Then four columns of silver nanospheres were put in the vicinity of the sensing fiber. A radius of 50 nm was used for the nanosphere and the surrounding medium was assumed to be air. In order to solve the near-field electromagnetic distribution near the sensing fiber with silver nanoparticles, the finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method, traced back to Yee,12 could be applied effectively. The analysis here is based on the FDTD solution software. The technique involves decomposing the computation domain into Yee cells, which are the basic element in three-dimensional FDTD analysis. In a Yee cell, the electric and magnetic field components are determined at discrete locations for a cell in each time step. Three-dimensional FDTD employs a central-differencing scheme for both spatial and temporal derivatives associated with the forms of the Maxwell Curl equations. The three-dimensional simulation layout of the model is shown in Figure 4.

caption.p: Three-dimensional simulation layout of the model.

sec.p: It can be clearly observed from Figure 5 that the scope of the evanescent field has been obviously enlarged and the amplitude of the evanescent field around the nanoparticles has been increased as well. There is no obvious local field enhancement around the core when there is no nanoparticle placed in the vicinity of the sensing fiber. The area of the evanescent field has been extended from 1 µm to 3 µm approximately, which can interact with the analytes in a relatively far-field scope. In addition, the energy of the evanescent scattering field can be enhanced by two to three times.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This paper proposes a novel method to improve the sensitivity of evanescent field optical fiber sensors through enlarging the evanescent field scope by nanoparticle scattering on the sensing fiber. It is proved that the scope of the evanescent field is suitable to be expanded by increasing the radius. The range of the evanescent field to the core–cladding interface can be extended from 1 µm to 3 µm by silver nanosphere scattering. When the radius of the nanoparticle increases, the scattering peak wavelength shifts red, the scattering effect becomes obvious, and the scattering efficiency reaches 74% of the extinction efficiency when the radius is 50 nm.
